moves.1. e4: My name is Fred Mcgriff, and I'm a retired Baseball professional.
moves.1... c5: Having just "read" The Safest Sicilian by Alexander Delchev with Semko Semkov, I am ready to bring my new knowledge to battle.  The hilarity that ensues will be my woeful regurgitation of this fine GM teaching.
moves.2. Nf3 e6: With this move I complete the book's subtitle, "A Black Repertoire with 1.e4 c5 2.nf3 e6"  Now I am ready to export some pain.  I feel almost omniscient.
moves.3. c3: Okay I remember ONE THING about c3, according to Delchev and Semkov, and that is, outright attack it!  Kill c3!!!
moves.3... Nf6: I dare you to move that e pawn.  Please move the e pawn.
moves.4... Nd5: my battle donkey takes a gorgeous slow-motion leap to d5, its sinewy haunches ripple majestically as it evades the deadly attack
moves.5. Bc4: what??  did you not see the haunches?!
moves.5... a6: must. kill. c3. at all costs.  I am a blind man with one purpose, to kill c3.  I cannot fail the friendly bulgarian GMs who have bestowed their hard-earned expertise upon me.
moves.6. Bxd5: white is being annoyingly aggressive.  my battle donkey's proud display of majesty obviously either went unnoticed or defiantly underestimated.
moves.6... exd5: doubled pawns, it's practically game over now for me.
moves.9. dxc5 Bxc5: I have an answer for almost everything.  I am parrying brilliantly.  My bishop reigns supreme over its g1-a7 diocese.  And Meanwhile, I am inches away from killing C3!
moves.10. Qxd5: Hmmm.  My rook... but... C3.... but my rook.... but...
moves.11. Nxc3: Well that was short-lived.  Now I have no idea what to do.  I have a rook about to get smashed and I no longer have anything on C3.  Thanks a lot, Delchev and Semkov.
moves.11... O-O: I castle here.   White can have the rook, I don't care.  I don't even know what to do anymore.  Delchev and Semkov hath forsaken me.
moves.12... Nc6: Now the greedy fat Queen is trapped in the corner.  You fat, greedy queen.  You are so fat.  Oh my god.  Wow.  Look how fat you are.
moves.13. Nd5: I just have to jockey some things around here and then I can take the queen.
moves.13... Qa5 14. Be3: White is going to lose a lot of material getting out of this mess
moves.29. h4 f6 30. e6: not sure what white's after here... he's got a crisis brewing by his king and chooses to advance the pawns
moves.30... g6 31. e7 Rxe7: the pawn is no match for my rook.  rook will win that matchup 95% of the time.
moves.32... Qxd1 33. Qxe7 Qxf3+: and I'm up a clergyman.  game, set, match, check please.
moves.34. Ke1 Qe4+: this will rule out any chance of a comeback.  shall we retire?  send us news of our victory.
moves.35. Qxe4 Bxe4 36. fxg6 Bxg6 37. bxa4 Be8: now the hilarious part is that white waited 2 days, 23 hours, and 59 minutes between each move from here on out.  which is really why i'm annotating this mess.
moves.40... Kf7 41. g5 fxg5 42. hxg5 hxg5: at this point i had so many conditional moves set up that I didn't have to ever look at this game again, yet he *still* waits 2 days, 23 hours, and 59 minutes between moves
moves.43. Ke3 g4 44. Kf4 c4 45. Kxg4 c3 46. Kf: seriously?  I have to spell this out?
